articles.headline: Amount of Spill Could Escalate, Company Admits
articles.snippet: A senior BP executive said the sunken oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico could spill as many as 60,000 barrels a day of oil, more than 10 times the estimate of the current flow.
articles.abstract: A senior BP executive said the sunken oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico could spill as many as 60,000 barrels a day of oil, more than 10 times the estimate of the current flow.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by John M. Broder, Campbell Robertson and Clifford Krauss.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder, Campbell Robertson and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Chicago Wins Prize as Home of Big Carrier
articles.snippet: Chicago’s efforts may have helped bring the combined Continental-United airline there, rather than Houston.
articles.abstract: Chicago’s efforts may have helped bring the combined Continental-United airline there, rather than Houston.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Richard M. Daley and other politicians stood with the leaders of United and Continental airlines in downtown Chicago on Tuesday, proudly underscoring plans that the proposed merged airline — to be the largest in the world — will have its headquarters here.

articles.headline: Rumblings in the New York Skies
articles.snippet: In merging with United, Continental gains a bigger flight network that would leave its rivals in New York — Delta Air Lines and American Airlines — struggling to catch up.
articles.abstract: In merging with United, Continental gains a bigger flight network that would leave its rivals in New York — Delta Air Lines and American Airlines — struggling to catch up.
articles.lead_paragraph: The combination of United and Continental Airlines would upend the balance of power at New York’s airports.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Patrick McGeehan

articles.headline: More With Dementia Wander From Home
articles.snippet: Search-and-rescue officials are facing a growing number of people with Alzheimer’s disease or other forms of dementia who wander from home.
articles.abstract: Search-and-rescue officials are facing a growing number of people with Alzheimer’s disease or other forms of dementia who wander from home.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASHBURN, Va. — For generations, the prototypical search-and-rescue case in America was Timmy in the well, with Lassie barking insistently to summon help. Lost children and adolescents — from the woods to the mall — generally outnumbered all others.

articles.headline: Bill Drops Fund to Shut Failed Banks
articles.snippet: Leaders of the Senate Banking Committee said that they agreed to limit the likelihood of a taxpayer bailout of big banks, but liberal Democrats said they would push for reducing the size of the nation’s biggest banks.
articles.abstract: Leaders of the Senate Banking Committee said that they agreed to limit the likelihood of a taxpayer bailout of big banks, but liberal Democrats said they would push for reducing the size of the nation’s biggest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leaders of the Senate Banking Committee said Tuesday that they had reached an agreement to limit the likelihood that big banks would be bailed out by taxpayers. But liberal Democrats said they also would push aggressively for an array of proposals that could force some of the nation’s biggest banks to reduce their size.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Crisis Panel to Probe Window-Dressing at Banks
articles.snippet: Many of the practices that enabled investment banks to mask deteriorating finances are still being employed.
articles.abstract: Many of the practices that enabled investment banks to mask deteriorating finances are still being employed.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s an open secret on Wall Street that many big banks routinely — and legally — fudge their quarterly books.
